abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second
            Telecommunications Project for Cote d'Ivoire was
            marginally satisfactory. The project achieved some of its
            objectives, its impact on institutional development was
            modest, sustainability is uncertain, and the performance of
            the Bank was satisfactory while the Borrower's was
            marginally unsatisfactory. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, the current separation of the
            training function from the operating entities of the sector
            is not sustainable and CI-TELECOM, in particular, should
            incorporate this training function into its human resource
            management function. Second, although organization was
            improved, more resources should have been allocated to
            develop effective tools of management, such as computerized
            billing, network management, and inventory and accounting
            systems. Third, the project exclusively focused on issues
            confronting the telecommunications operating entity without
            encompassing broader issues, such as the Government's
            prerogatives, role, and responsibilities toward the sector,
            and the respective role and mission of the
            telecommunications operator as well as the private sector in
            the development of infrastructure and provision of services.
            Finally, the intensity of Bank supervision was too low
            during the critical build-up of the project. A formal
            mid-term review would have been useful to review and
            reassess the project's risks.
